awd_titl_txt: Functional Evolution of the FRUITFULL Gene Lineage in the Tomato Family (Solanaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Because plants are rooted in the ground, they must have ways for their offspring to move away from home, to colonize new areas.  Seeds are usually produced in one of two types of vessels to facilitate this process.  A dry pod splits open at maturity to release the seeds, so they can be carried on the wind or, if they have hooks, they can stick to an animal.  In contrast, a fleshy fruit such as an apple or cucumber will be eaten by an animal, which will then disperse the seeds.  Fleshy fruits provide an important source of nutrition to all animals, including humans; a large part of the human diet and economy is based on fruits such as tomatoes, peppers, melons, squash, or avocados.  Many different groups of flowering plants underwent an evolutionary shift from producing a dry pod to a fleshy fruit, with important ecological and economic consequences.  The long-term goal of this project is to understand the genetic mechanisms that determine if a plant will produce a dry pod or an edible, fleshy fruit.  The work focuses on the nightshade family, which includes pod-producing species such as desert tobacco and petunia, as well as fleshy-fruit-producing species such as tomato, eggplant, and pepper.  These experiments look at the role of a group of genes that appears to have undergone a change in function associated with the origin of fleshy fruit.  The results may identify specific genes or changes in genes that allow a species to make an edible, nutritious fruit, which could contribute to crop improvement or development.  This project also will form the basis of two botanical garden exhibits on fruit structure and diversity in the nightshade family, and will provide training for high school students and undergraduates from under-represented minorities, as well as for a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher. 

The MADS-box transcription factor FRUITFULL (FUL) plays a key role in the development of the Arabidopsis fruit by determining the patterns of cell differentiation that are required for the fruit to elongate and split open normally to release the seeds. FUL orthologs have also been shown to be required for proper ripening in some fleshy fruits, showing a conserved function in fruit development, but with a substantially different outcome.  Fruits in the nightshade family (Solanaceae) are ancestrally dry and dehiscent, but there was a shift to fleshy fruit with the origin of the Solanoideae clade.  The FUL gene clade has undergone duplications leading to four copies in some species, and the first part of this project will generate a gene tree using a combination of transcriptome and targeted PCR approaches to identify when duplications occurred. The data will also be used to determine whether different paralogous clades have undergone different modes of evolution (neutral, purifying, etc), which will be correlated with the functional data collected in the second part.  The second part uses CRISPR technology to compare the function of the four FUL paralogs in desert tobacco and tomato to determine how the function of each paralog changed during Solanaceae evolution.  Double and quadruple mutants will also be evaluated and transcriptomes generated to determine the effect of downregulation on downstream targets in both dry and fleshy fruit development.  The focus will be on early stages of development, prior to ripening and dehiscence, when defining characteristics such as pericarp thickness and cell type identity are specified.  The data will contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms required to produce a fleshy fruit, and will elucidate the processes underlying a key evolutionary phenomenon, the shift from dry to fleshy fruit production.  All data will be publicly available upon publication through GenBank, Sol Genomics Network, and the Dryad repository.  Mutant lines and seed will be available upon request from the investigators.

por.por_cntn:
In the nightshade family (Solanaceae), the ancestral fruit type is a dry capsule, and is produced by species such as tobacco and petunia.  During the evolution of the family, there was a switch to fleshy edible fruit, such as those found in tomato and chili pepper. This switch has important implications, both economic and ecological.  FRUITULL genes have been shown to play a key role in the development of dry capsule-like fruit in the mustard species Arabidopsis thaliana. This project was designed to test if they have the same function in nightshades, and to evaluate their role in fleshy fruit development.  Whereas most species have two of these genes, nightshades have duplicates of each of the two.  We found that whereas one pair appears to have arisen from a whole genome duplication, the other pair appear to be a more recent tandem duplication of a chromosome segment.  Further, we were able to capture one of the latter pair in the process of becoming a non-functional gene; it is expressed at very low levels (often missed entirely in studies), is lacking hundreds of base pairs of regulatory sequence, and is accumulating mutations at a much higher rate.  We found that there were no changes in sequence or expression associated with the shift from dry to fleshy fruit, suggesting the shift was not related to a change in the function of these genes (Maheepala et al. American Journal of Botany 2019).

We characterized the function of these genes in desert tobacco, which produces a dry fruit, to see if the function was the same as that shown in other model species (as yet unpublished). We found that reducing the expression of these genes resulted in dwarfed plants with increased branching. We also found that the sepals, which remain attached to the developing capsule, did not dry properly; they remained green and sticky, which prevented seeds from dispersing properly.  Thus these genes are required for efficient reproduction.  However, we saw no defects in fruit development of any kind, suggesting these genes do not function in capsule development in nightshades as they do in Arabidopsis.

Jimson weed (Datura) is closely related to the fleshy-fruited tomato but produces a dry capsule-type fruit.  We are interested in whether Datura uses the same molecular mechanisms to produce a dry fruit as other species.  However, Datura completely lacked genomic resources.  We developed a stable transformation protocol (Rajewski et al. APPS 2019), and sequenced, assembled, and annotated the genome sequence (Rajewski et al. BMC Genomics 2021).  We found that genes involved in the metabolism of alkaloids, compounds that are both medically important and highly toxic, are over-represented in the genome, consistent with the high level of toxicity of these species as well as their importance in indigenous practices.  

We also generated genome-wide gene expression data from five different developmental stages from three nightshade species: desert tobacco, wild tomato, and cultivated tomato.  Comparing dry to fleshy and wild to domesticated allowed us to identify distinct patterns of expression that might differentiate the fruit types. To make this more universal, we added data from Arabidopsis and melon. These distantly related species allowed us to look for genes with universally conserved expression patterns, as well as dry- and fleshy-fruit specific conserved patterns (Rajewski et al. submitted, Frontiers in Plant Science).  We found 120 genes that showed the same pattern across all 5 species. These genes were involved in processes such as cell division, DNA replication, signaling, and similar common functions.  This is expected because it is only at this level that dry and fleshy fruits are similar.  In contrast, we found over 1000 genes with expression patterns that differed between dry and fleshy, but were conserved within each fruit type.  These genes included important developmental regulators, as well as genes involved in the processes that differentiate the fruit types (accumulation of sugars etc. in fleshy fruit, development of woody tissue, etc. in dry fruit). These genes give us a place to start future exploration of the gene functions that make fleshy fruit fleshy.

One final project, still being completed, is comparing DNA methylation in wild and cultivated tomato.  We have generated data for 9 different collections of wild tomato, and four of cultivated, and have found fixed differences in methylation patterns that may explain some of the differences in gene expression that can?t be explained by differences in sequence.  This information will help guide studies aimed at introducing important traits from wild into cultivated tomato, as well as improvement of cultivated tomato.

This project trained three graduate students and one post-doctoral researches, all members of under-represented communities, as well as 15 undergraduates, 9 of whom are members of under-represented communities.  All of these who have graduated have remained in plant biology or biological science research in some capacity.
